hints.label: def-gauge-invariant-function
hints.title: Gauge-Invariant Function
hints.content:
205: :label: def-gauge-invariant-function
206: 
207: A function $f: \Sigma_N \to \mathbb{R}$ is **gauge-invariant** (or **$S_N$-invariant**) if:
208: 
209: $$
210: f(\sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}) = f(\mathcal{S})
211: 
212: $$
213: 
214: for all $\sigma \in S_N$ and $\mathcal{S} \in \Sigma_N$.
215: 
216: The space of gauge-invariant functions is:
217: 
218: $$
219: C(\Sigma_N)^{S_N} = \{f \in C(\Sigma_N) : f \text{ is } S_N\text{-invariant}\}
hints.raw_directive:

224: :::{prf:theorem} Descent to Configuration Space
225: :label: thm-descent-theorem
226:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-38
hints.content:
238: 
239: :::{prf:proof}
240: **Well-definedness of descent**: If $f$ is $S_N$-invariant and $[\mathcal{S}] = [\mathcal{S}']$, then $\mathcal{S}' = \sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}$ for some $\sigma \in S_N$, so:
241: 
242: $$
243: f(\mathcal{S}') = f(\sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}) = f(\mathcal{S})
244: 
245: $$
246: 
247: Thus $\bar{f}$ is well-defined on orbits.
248: 
249: **Injectivity**: If $\bar{f}_1 = \bar{f}_2$, then $f_1(\mathcal{S}) = \bar{f}_1([\mathcal{S}]) = \bar{f}_2([\mathcal{S}]) = f_2(\mathcal{S})$.
250: 
251: **Surjectivity**: Any $\bar{f} \in C(\mathcal{M}_{\text{config}})$ pulls back to an $S_N$-invariant function $f = \bar{f} \circ \pi_G$.
